awd_titl_txt: New Directions in Bayesian Change-Point Analysis
awd_abstract_narration:
Almost all dynamic and random processes in nature go through sudden and significant structural changes. Often the change is in the observable quantity, e.g. fuel prices or stock indices or crime activities changing significantly in response to a change in an unobservable, latent factor such as an economic phenomenon or a public policy change, or a disease outbreak. Such ‘change-points’ are routinely observed across all scientific disciplines and applications, such as economics, epidemiology, social sciences, cybersecurity and finance. Specific examples could be changing regression when the observed variable depends on predictors through a mean structure that changes with time, or change points in data with massive dimensions, such as high-resolution imaging data or complex connected graphs. While there is a substantial literature proposing elaborate methods for detecting change points in different settings, there has been limited consideration of Bayesian methods for change-points in hierarchical models with complex dependence or sparsity structures. This research fills this gap with new statistical tools motivated by specific real-life applications, by developing theoretical framework while retaining efficiency and usefulness in current applications. The project integrates graduate education and training with statistical research, and emphasizes upholding societal and ethical considerations that create and foster an inclusive and diverse community.

In higher dimensions, the problem of detecting change-points and the changing structure is often rendered extremely difficult owing to a combinatorial computational complexity. Through this research, the PIs outline a comprehensive framework, both theoretical and methodological, in the context of change point estimation encompassing problems that may arise in different field of applications. In particular, the PIs build fundamentally new Bayesian methods that can 1) perform sparse signal recovery in a changing linear regression with consistency guarantees 2) detect change-points in dependence structure via changes in a Gaussian graphical model, and 3) build an innovative method for handling ‘ultra-high’-dimensional objects via random projections to drastically reduce the computational burden. Theoretical machinery will be developed to provide probabilistic rigor and consistency guarantee. Computationally efficient algorithms will be developed, and user-friendly software tools will be deployed in R for the usage of the developed methods by the scientific community at large.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In many applications such as economics, social science, or genomics, sudden structural changes take place, based on changes in some latent unobserved factor such as an economic phenomenon or public policy change or exposure to an external stimulus. The structural change may be local, i.e., only limited to a few time segments or global, and selecting the changepoints while learning the underlying structure consistently remains an important problem which provides an insight into the underlying phenomenon. The overarching goal of this project is to develop novel statistical tools for changepoint analysis, that address key challenges in detecting structural changes in high-dimensional and ultra-high-dimensional data. The key research thrusts of this project were to (a) consistent selection of change-points and predictor variables in a high-dimensional changing linear model, (b) estimation of change-points in the underlying dependence structure encoded by a dynamic graphical model and (c) detecting change-points in ultra-high dimensional observations such as high-resolution image data.

This research has been successful in providing the first detailed theoretical analysis for posterior consistency in Bayesian changepoint models, ensuring both theoretical rigor and practical applicability. We have utilized state-of-the-art Bayesian tools for sparse signal recovery and random projection methods to address the potentially large number of predictor variables as well as the ultra-high dimensionality of observed data. The project has also resulted in a rich collection of methodological and computational tools, e.g., novel methodologies for structure learning, and joint modeling of mean and covariance and improved majorization-minimization algorithm that support the research problems developed in this proposal and beyond. The key findings from this research have been published in leading journals, including Bayesian Analysis, Biometrics, Electronic Journal of Statistics, and Journal of Multivariate Analysis, ensuring widespread dissemination among statisticians and scientists. Additionally, results have been presented at top international conferences such as the Joint Statistical Meetings (JSM), the International Indian Statistical Association (IISA) Conference, and the New England Statistical Society (NESS) Symposium. The developed methods have been successfully applied across disciplines, including genomics, social sciences, crime forecasting, and environmental monitoring. Open-source software implementations of these methods are now available, promoting accessibility and adoption by a broader research community. Beyond scientific impact, the project’s findings have important societal applications, such as improving economic forecasting, healthcare anomaly detection, and public safety decision-making. By bridging theoretical advancements with real-world applications, this research has laid the foundation for scalable, interpretable, and robust statistical modeling in dynamic data environments.
